subject: Re: [junit] OT: Streams / Readers/ Writers or files, what do you use and how do you test?

messageBody:
Hi Cédric,

> It's convenient when you want to do line-oriented filtering (e.g. regexp,
> parsing logs, etc...). You can always use a BufferedReader + readLine(),
> but it's still more tedious to write than just having an String[] returned
> from a public method.
>
> It's admittedly not as effective memory-wise, but when you're dealing with
> text files that are in the tens of k's, it doesn't really matter.

I cooked up a small program to get a feeling for the difference.
I assumed that the method would be called something like readLines and
return a string array. I also assumed that the method would throw an
IOException to indicate when there was a problem.

public void processReader(Reader reader) throws IOException {
BufferedReader bufferedReader = new BufferedReader(reader);
String line;

while( (line = bufferedReader.readLine()) != null ) {
processLine(line);
}
}

public void processFile(File file) throws IOException {
String [] lines = file.readLines();
for(String line : lines) {
processLine(line);
}
}


private void processLine(String line) {
// TODO Auto-generated method stub
}


Conclusions about the implemengtation:

In the implementation files with the suggested extension or using a
buffered reader is similarily complex.

But there is still one aspect that has not yet been addressed. Using the method:

public void useReader(String name) throws IOException {
Reader reader = new FileReader(name);
try {
processReader(reader);
}
finally {
reader.close();
}
}

public void useFile(String name) throws IOException {
File file = new File(name);
processFile(file);
}


Conclusion about usage:

It is more tedious to use a reader since you have to remeber that you
should close it and decide who closes it (I assume readLines takes
care of that in the file example). If you don't close it you can leak
resources.

So I would have to agree with you about tediousness. Summing it all
up, implementation, usage, testability, consistency and flexibility I
would still go for the stream option but it is clearer to me now that
it is a less obvious choice.

I have a nice pattern to deal with streams so that you cannot leak
resources but that is a different topic and it would have to be used
in a few places to make sense.

Interesting...
/Joakim Ohlrogge
